I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Promoting regional cooperation and integration is one of the strategic priorities in the 
Long-Term Strategic Framework (2001–2015) and the Medium-Term Strategy II (2006–2008) of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 ADB has played a crucial role in promoting regional 
cooperation  through  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Program. 
Initiated in 1997 with the support of six multilateral institutions,2 the Program aims to strengthen 
economic linkages among Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, People’s Republic of China (PRC; with 
focus on the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region), Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, 
Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. Transport has been identified as a priority under CAREC and ADB is 
the lead agency in coordinating transport cooperation activities. 
 
2.  The Fourth Ministerial Conference on CAREC, held in Bishkek, Kyrgyz Republic on 5–6 
November 2005, called for a transport sector strategy that reflects new trade realities and that 
will lead to sharp reductions in the time and costs of moving goods and freight to both internal 
and external markets.3 In response, this regional technical assistance (TA)4 was included in the 
2006 program. The TA concept paper was approved by the Management on 13 July 2006, and 
endorsed  by  CAREC  countries  at  the  Sixth  Meeting  of  the  Transport  Sector  Coordinating 
Committee (TSCC) and the subsequent Senior Officials’ meeting, both held in Urumqi, the PRC 
in August 2006. Concurrence was reached with the CAREC governments on the TA’s impact, 
outcome, outputs, cost, financing and implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of 
reference.5 The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Central Asia is landlocked; therefore high transport costs are a major constraint to its 
development.  Meanwhile,  Central  Asia  has  a  potential  to  become  important  transit  routes 
connecting East Asia and Europe, as well as South Asia and the Russian Federation. Regional 
cooperation in transport is vital to reduce transport costs and increase trade that will contribute 
to sustainable development and poverty reduction in CAREC countries. Transport cooperation 
under CAREC so far has been guided by a regional transport sector road map (2005–2010) 
endorsed at the Third TSCC Meeting in March 2005 in Bishkek, Kyrgyz Republic. However, 
recent developments warrant the formulation of a CAREC transport sector strategy. First, the 
Fourth CAREC Ministerial Conference in November 2005 called for a transport sector strategy. 
Second, external trade in CAREC countries has expanded rapidly since 2003, primarily because 
of higher commodity prices6 and large inflows of foreign direct investment into the export-
oriented sector. The strong trade growth has increased the demand for an efficient regional 
transport  network,  thus  requiring  systematic  analysis  and  responses  through  a  CAREC 
transport sector strategy. Third, Afghanistan joined the CAREC Program in October 2005. As 
Afghanistan is a potentially important route to markets in Central Asia, a CAREC transport 
sector strategy is needed to identify new opportunities for expanding the scope of regional

cooperation. Fourth, the Regional Sector Road Map (2005–2010) covers only roads, railways, 
and civil aviation. A CAREC transport sector strategy covering all modes of transport (i.e., roads, 
railways, civil aviation, and waterways) is needed to bring down transport costs and barriers 
through regional cooperation. 
 
4.  The CAREC transport sector strategy should be developed in the context of global and 
regional developments. There are two salient global and regional development trends. First, 
globalization has resulted in profound changes in global production structures and supply chains. 
Second, CAREC countries have achieved economic growth over the past years. In particular, 
the Central Asian transition economies have ended the decade-long contraction and national 
outputs have reached, or have been close to, their pre-independence levels. However, growth 
across CAREC countries varied significantly. These developments pose three challenges to the 
CAREC Program. First, globalization is likely to change supply chains in CAREC countries, thus 
affecting their trade and traffic flows. Second, unless an efficient regional transport network is in 
place to respond to new global and regional supply chains, the competitiveness of CAREC 
countries cannot be improved significantly. Third, sustained regional transport cooperation is 
critically dependent on fair distribution of the costs and benefits of regional transport networks 
among CAREC countries. The CAREC transport sector strategy will address these challenges. 
 
5.  The development of economic corridors has recently been promoted under CAREC.7 An 
economic corridor refers to a geographic area where commercial activities are concentrated and 
is  thus  beyond  the  boundary  of  a  single  sector,  but  transport  plays  an  important  role  in 
promoting economic corridor development. Through efficient movements of goods and people, 
transport links the businesses located along an economic corridor to global and regional supply 
chains  and  markets  The  CAREC  transport  sector  strategy  will  recommend  best  ways  to 
maximize transport’s contribution to the development of economic corridors. 
 
6.  Initially, transport infrastructure has been the backbone of transport cooperation under 
CAREC.  Regional  transport  infrastructure  strengthens  physical  connectivity  among  CAREC 
countries and links CAREC countries to world markets. With the assistance of ADB and other 
external  aid  agencies,  CAREC  countries  have  made  efforts  to  improve  regional  transport 
corridors. Investments were made to rehabilitate cross-border roads and national roads with 
regional  implications.8 Studies  were  conducted  to  identify  regional  transport  corridors  and 
examine the feasibility of improvement.9 However, transport links among CAREC countries 
remain limited; a large proportion of the existing regional transport infrastructure is deteriorating; 
and a multimodal, integrated regional transport network is lacking. With the use of forecast trade 
and traffic flows, the CAREC transport sector strategy will identify optimum regional transport 
corridors and propose ways to develop those corridors. 
 
7.  Cross-border  facilitation  has  become  an  important  element  of  transport  cooperation 
under  CAREC.  Together  with  international  development  partners,  ADB  has  supported  the

efforts of CAREC countries to improve border facilities and develop cross-border agreements. A 
Cross-Border Transport Agreement between Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic regarding the 
Akzhol–Chu border was signed in 2001 to facilitate road transport between Almaty and Bishkek. 
A  study  on  harmonizing  regional  transport  regulations  and  cross-border  agreements  was 
conducted and an action plan, which was developed based on the study, was endorsed at the 
Sixth TSCC Meeting in August 2006. ADB, in cooperation with the United Nations Economic 
and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  is  assisting  the  Shanghai  Cooperation 
Organization  (SCO)  member  states,  which  are  largely  identical  to  CAREC  countries,  in 
formulating an agreement on facilitating international road transport.10 ADB is also helping 
improve  border  facilities  and  strengthen  border  officers’  capacity  in  CAREC  countries.11 
Nevertheless, cross-border movements among CAREC countries remain largely inefficient due 
to  nonharmonized  policies  and  procedures,  and  inadequate  border  facilities.  Cross-border 
facilitation also requires cooperative efforts from all agencies serving at borders, including 
immigration control, customs, and the agency for goods inspection and quarantine. The CAREC 
transport sector strategy will address these issues. 
 
8.  The regional transport network in Central Asia comprises railways, roads, civil aviation, 
and  waterways.  An  integrated  multimodal  regional  transport  system  is  essential  to  reduce 
transport  costs  and  foster  trade,  investment,  and  other  economic  activities.  The  CAREC 
transport sector strategy to be developed will be based on an integrated, multimodal transport 
approach.  This  approach  require  developing  well-linked  multimodal  transport  infrastructure, 
harmonizing regulations and procedures set by modal agencies, and addressing multimodal 
logistic issues through cooperation among all transport modal agencies. 
 
9.  There is an opportunity for public-private partnerships (PPPs) in transport cooperation 
under CAREC. The CAREC Program has primarily involved governments to date.12 Strong 
efforts are needed to develop effective mechanisms for public-private dialogue, and encourage 
private investments and service provision for regional transport. The CAREC transport sector 
strategy will propose measures to enhance PPPs in regional transport. 
  
10.  Development of an efficient CAREC regional transport network is associated with some 
social and environmental issues, which need to be tackled through regional cooperation. Where 
new transport corridors are developed, access to them may sometimes be unaffordable to low-
income  groups.  Improvement  of  transport  infrastructure  may  also  have  impacts  on  traffic 
accidents,  pollution,  HIV/AIDS,  infectious  diseases,  and  human  and  drug  trafficking.  The 
CAREC transport sector strategy will take these issues into account to overcome negative 
externalities of regional transport development. 
 
11.  In  addition  to  the  CAREC  Program,  there  are  several  other  regional  cooperation 
initiatives covering CAREC countries. The major initiatives include the Central and South Asia 
Transport  and  Trade  Forum,  Economic  Cooperation  Organization,  Eurasian  Economic 
Community, SCO, and the Special Programme for the Economies of Central Asia. The CAREC 
transport sector strategy will be formulated in collaboration with these initiatives.

12.  The TA is consistent with ADB’s CAREC regional cooperation strategy and program. 
The latest CAREC regional cooperation strategy and program update13 reconfirms transport as 
a  priority  for  CAREC  and  for  ADB  support.  The  CAREC  transport  sector  strategy  will  be 
developed in line with the CAREC regional cooperation strategy and program. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The TA will have impacts on sustainable economic development and poverty reduction 
in CAREC countries as a result of regional transport cooperation. The TA aims to formulate a 
CAREC transport sector strategy that will guide CAREC cooperation activities to develop an 
efficient regional transport network for optimal integration of the region internally and with the 
rest of the world. The TA will have two outputs: (i) an analytical overview of CAREC regional 
transport networks and cross-border arrangements, and (ii) a CAREC transport sector strategy. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. Phase I will give an overview of CAREC 
regional  transport  networks  and  cross-border  arrangements.  The  overview  will  cover  the 
following areas: (i) existing regional transport infrastructure networks and services; (ii) demand 
for regional and transit transport of freight and passengers; (iii) modal shares of cross-border 
transport; (iv) cross-border facilities, arrangements, and logistics; (v) policies, legislation, and 
regulations  on  cross-border  transport;  (vi)  financing  for  regional  transport  infrastructure 
(including investment and maintenance) and services; (vii) institutional and human resource 
capacity  for  cross-border  transport;  (viii)  status  of  PPPs in  regional transport;  (ix)  national 
transport sector strategies or master plans in CAREC countries from a regional perspective; and 
(x)  existing  regional  transport  studies  by  CAREC  countries,  ADB,  and  other  development 
partners. Based on the outcome of Phase I, Phase II will develop a CAREC transport sector 
strategy. The strategy will focus on Central Asia and will link other CAREC countries to Central 
Asia.  The  strategy  will  (i)  identify  the  long-term  challenges  for  CAREC  regional  transport 
cooperation and development, (ii) assess the impact of new global supply chains on CAREC 
regional trade and traffic flows, (iii) forecast the demand for regional and transit trade and 
transport, (iv) set strategic priorities for regional transport development through cooperation, (v) 
identify key (up to 6) regional transport corridors based on the analysis of trade flows, (vi) 
specify the role of each transport mode in the regional transport network, (vii) identify further 
policy and institutional reforms needed to promote regional traffic and improve management and 
maintenance  of  regional  transport  corridors,  (viii)  propose  measures  to  enhance  PPPs  in 
regional transport, (ix) propose measures to improve cross-border logistics, (x) develop a time-
bound  implementation  plan,  and  (xi)  specify  the  resources  required  for  implementing  the 
CAREC transport sector strategy. 
 
15.  The  TA  was  designed  in  consultation  with  stakeholders  in  the  public,  private,  and 
nonprofit sectors, as well as international development partners. The TA was initiated at the 
Fifth TSCC Meeting in March 2006, and the TA proposal was endorsed at the Sixth TSCC 
Meeting in August 2006. The comments made at the TSCC meetings were incorporated into the 
TA design. During TA implementation, stakeholder consultation will continue through country-
based meetings and three regional workshops—the first, to finalize the work program and the 
consultants’ terms of reference during the initial implementation period; the second, to discuss

the  draft  report  on  the  overview  of  CAREC  regional  transport  networks  and  cross-border 
arrangements; and the third, to discuss the draft CAREC transport sector strategy. 
 
16.  The CAREC transport sector strategy will be developed taking into account the national 
transport sector strategies or master plans in CAREC countries. It will adopt an integrated 
multimodal transport approach covering roads, railways, civil aviation, and waterways.14 It will 
be  formulated  in  coordination  with  ADB’s  proposed  regional  technical  assistance  for  trade 
facilitation and other regional cooperation initiatives in Central Asia. 
 
17.  Key TA activities will be (i) reviews of existing documents, studies, and reports; (ii) data 
analysis; (iii) office research; (iv) field surveys; and (v) stakeholder consultation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $950,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the Executing Agency. The Infrastructure Division, Central and West Asia 
Department of ADB, will be responsible for administering the TA. The TA will be implemented in 
collaboration with ADB’s other relevant departments and resident missions in CAREC countries, 
multilateral institutions involved in the CAREC Program, and relevant government agencies in 
CAREC countries. 
 
20.  The TA will require 32 person-months of international consulting inputs to be provided by 
an  international  consulting  firm.  The  team  of  international  consultants  will  comprise  (i)  a 
transport planner/team leader, (ii) a macro and trade economist, (iii) a transport economist, (iv) 
a  freight  transport  specialist,  (v)  a  passenger  transport  specialist,  and  (vi)  a  cross-border 
facilitation/logistic  specialist.  Domestic  consultants  in  selected  CAREC  countries  may  be 
engaged  for  up  to  26  person-months  to  support  the  international  consultants’  work.  The 
composition of domestic consultants will be proposed by the international consultants as needs 
are identified during TA implementation. The terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 
3. All consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants, using the quality- and cost-based selection procedures and simplified technical 
proposals. 
 
21.  The TA is expected to start in February 2007 and to be completed at the end of 
December 2007. The TA outputs will be presented at TSCC meetings for endorsement, and 
disseminated  to  the  public  through  regional  workshops  and  the  ADB  website  upon  TA 
completion. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis for 
the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation: Transport Sector Strategy Study, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) aims to formulate a clear and comprehensive Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) transport sector strategy that will guide CAREC 
cooperation activities to develop an efficient regional transport network for optimal integration of 
the region internally and with the rest of the world. The TA will have two outputs: (i) an analytical 
overview of CAREC regional transport networks and cross-border arrangements; and (ii) a 
CAREC transport sector strategy. 
 
2.  The TA will be implemented in 2007 and in two phases. Phase I (February–July 2007) 
will result in an overview of CAREC regional transport networks and cross-border arrangements. 
Phase I will be initiated by a fact-finding mission comprising the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
staff and the consultant team leader to selected CAREC countries to fine tune the methodology 
of the study and discuss the venue of regional workshops. In Phase II (July–December 2007), a 
CAREC transport sector strategy will be developed, using the outcome of Phase I. 
 
3.  The TA will require 32 person-months of international consulting inputs to be provided by 
an international consulting firm. Domestic consultants in selected CAREC countries may be 
engaged for up to 26 person-months to support international consultants’ work. All consultants 
will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, using the 
quality- and cost-based selection procedures and simplified technical proposals. 
 
B.  Consultants’ Tasks 
4.  The consultants’ tasks will include, but will not be limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  Produce a comprehensive and analytical overview of CAREC regional transport 
networks  and  cross-border  arrangements.  The  overview  should  cover  (a) 
regional transport infrastructure networks and services; (b) demand for regional 
and transit transport of freight and passengers; (c) modal shares of cross-border 
transport; (d) cross-border facilities, arrangements, and logistics; (e) policies, 
legislation, and regulations on cross-border transport; (f) financing and financial 
management capacity for regional transport infrastructure (including investment 
and maintenance) and services; (g) institutional and human resource capacity for 
cross-border  transport;  (h)  status  of  private-public  partnerships  in  regional 
transport;  (i)  national  transport  sector  strategies  or  master  plans  in  CAREC 
countries from a regional perspective to identify key gaps in regional transport 
links; and (j) existing regional transport studies by CAREC countries, ADB, and 
other development partners. On the basis of the review, the consultants will 
prepare a report, which will be presented at the second regional consultative 
workshop. Based on the comments received from workshop participants and 
CAREC governments, the consultants will finalize the report. 
 
(ii)  Identify the long-term challenges for CAREC regional transport cooperation and 
development, taking into account (a) global and regional context, (b) national 
development strategies in CAREC countries, (c) the experience of the CAREC 
Program, and (d) other regional transport cooperation initiatives. The consultants 
will also assess the responses of CAREC countries and the CAREC Program to 
these challenges.

(iii)  Assess the impact of new global production structures and supply chains on 
CAREC  regional  trade  and  traffic  flows,  identify  ongoing  efforts  in  CAREC 
countries to adjust to new global production structures and supply chains, and 
recommend best ways for the transport sector to respond to the impact. 
 
(iv)  Assess the role of the transport sector in developing economic corridors, and 
propose best ways to maximize transport’s contribution to economic corridor 
development under CAREC. 
 
(v)  Consider the impact of sector, social, and environmental issues associated with 
CAREC  regional  transport  development.  The  issues  include  traffic  safety, 
affordability,  pollution,  HIV/AIDS,  infectious  diseases,  and  human  and  drug 
trafficking. The consultants will review ongoing efforts in CAREC countries in 
these areas, and recommend measures to overcome negative externalities of 
CAREC regional transport development through cooperation. 
 
(vi)  Conduct public consultations on the formulation of the CAREC transport sector 
strategy.  The  consultants  will  hold  country-based  public  consultation  with 
stakeholders  including  government  officials,  civil  society,  nongovernment 
organizations, user groups, the private sector, and international development 
partners. The consultants will organize three regional consultative workshops to 
be attended by representatives of CAREC governments. The first workshop will 
be held in the initial period of services to finalize the work program and the terms 
of reference; the second, to discuss the draft report on the overview of CAREC 
regional transport networks and cross-border arrangements; and the third, to 
discuss the draft CAREC transport sector strategy. 
 
(vii)  In  preparing  the  strategy,  the  experience  of  other  more  advanced  regional 
initiatives (e.g., the Trans-European networks of the European Union and the 
Greater Mekong Subregion) should be considered. 
 
(viii)  Prepare a CAREC transport sector strategy based on the sector review and 
stakeholder consultation. The strategy will focus on Central Asia and will link 
other CAREC countries to Central Asia. The strategy should adopt an integrated 
multimodal  transport  approach  covering  roads,  railways,  civil  aviation,  and 
waterways. The strategy will (a) identify the long-term challenges for CAREC 
regional transport cooperation and development, (b) assess the impact of new 
global supply chains on CAREC regional trade and traffic flows; (c) forecast the 
demand for regional and transit trade and transport; (d) set strategic priorities for 
regional transport development through cooperation; (e) identify key (up to 6) 
regional transport corridors based on the analysis of trade flows; (f) specify the 
role  of  each  transport  mode  in  the  regional  transport  network  and  propose 
measures  to  improve  multimodal  transport;  (g)  identify  further  policy  and 
institutional reforms needed to promote regional traffic and improve management 
and  maintenance  of  regional  transport  corridors;  (h)  propose  measures  to 
enhance private-public partnerships in regional transport; (i) propose measures 
to improve cross-border logistics; (j) develop a time-bound implementation plan; 
and (k) specify the resources required for implementing the CAREC transport 
sector strategy. The consultants will present the draft CAREC transport sector 
strategy at the third regional consultative workshop. Considering the comments

received from workshop participants and CAREC governments, the consultants 
will finalize the CAREC transport sector strategy. 
 
(ix)  The CAREC transport sector strategy should be formulated in coordination with 
ADB’s  proposed  regional  technical  assistance  for  trade  facilitation  and  other 
regional cooperation initiatives covering CAREC countries, including the Central 
and South Asia Transport and Trade Forum, Economic Cooperation Organization, 
Eurasian Economic Community, the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and the 
Special Programme for the Economies of Central Asia. 
 
C.  Composition of Consultants 
5.  The  team  of  international  consultants  comprises  six  members  (person-months  in 
parentheses): (i) a transport planner (8.0), (ii) a macro and trade economist (5.0), (iii) a transport 
economist (5.0), (iv) a freight transport specialist (5.5), (v) a passenger transport specialist (4.0), 
and (vi) a cross-border facilitation/logistic specialist (4.5). The transport planner will also serve 
as team leader, responsible for coordinating with other consultants and preparing TA outputs. 
 
6.  The composition of domestic consultants will be proposed by international consultants 
as needs are identified during TA implementation. Under the supervision of the international 
consultants, the domestic consultants will assist in (i) collecting data and information from 
national and local sources; (ii) reviewing existing relevant documents, studies, and reports; (iii) 
organizing  country-based  consultations  with  stakeholders;  (iv)  conducting  field  surveys;  (v) 
providing inputs for TA reports; and (vi) performing other tasks as needed. 
 
D.  Reporting Requirements 
7.  The consultants will be required to submit to the CAREC governments and ADB, in a 
format satisfactory to ADB,  (i) an inception report within 4 weeks after services start; (ii) the 
draft Overview of CAREC Regional Transport Networks and Cross-Border Arrangements within 
20 weeks after services start; (iii) the draft CAREC Transport Sector Strategy within 36 weeks 
after services start; and (iv) the final forms of the Overview of CAREC Regional Transport 
Networks and Cross-Border Arrangements and the CAREC Transport Sector Strategy within 4 
weeks  after  receipt  of  comments  at  the  regional  workshops.  The  consultants  will  also  be 
required to submit brief TA progress reports to ADB and the CAREC countries each month 
during the services.
